awd_titl_txt: RII Track-2 FEC: Developmental Chronnecto-Genomics (Dev-CoG): A Next Generation Framework for Quantifying Brain Dynamics and Related Genetic Factors in Childhood
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description
This Research Infrastructure Improvement Track-2 Focused EPSCoR* Collaborations (RII Track-2 FEC) project has The MIND Research Network in New Mexico as the lead and Tulane University, the University of Nebraska Medical Center, and the University of Nebraska, Omaha as partners in a collaboration between 3 jurisdictions. The overarching goal is to understand the rapid development of human brain connectivity that occurs during late childhood and early adolescence.  Researchers will use multiple imaging modalities over multiple time scales, and develop novel mathematical algorithms for modeling and data analysis.  The project will involve five early career faculty and will engage students from middle school through graduate school in outreach and research activities.

Technical Description
The neuroscience research has four integrated components: (1) acquisition of neuroimaging and genetic data across this developmental time period, using magneto-encephalography (MEG), functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), diffusion MRI (dMRI) and genotyping; (2) unimodal analysis to advance understanding of time-varying brain connectivity by modeling neural oscillations measured with MEG, computing instantaneous whole brain connectivity networks via MEG and fMRI, and quantifying the evolution of whole brain connectivity patterns over time; (3) data fusion focused on the development and application of algorithms for bringing together multiple imaging and genetics parameters, behavior, and longitudinal components; and, (4) a workforce development and education program that includes outreach to middle, high school and community college students, research experiences for undergraduates, graduate-level interdisciplinary training, and faculty training workshops in neuroimaging and data modeling.

*Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Developmental Chronnecto-Genomics (Dev-CoG) Study, funded through the NSF’s EPSCOR mechanism, was designed to enhance multimodal neuroimaging expertise across three jurisdictions, New Mexico, Nebraska, and Louisiana. This was accomplished by conducting a large, multisite neuroimaging study focused on understanding neurodevelopment in typically developing children and by developing novel multimodal analysis techniques. The dataset represents the largest longitudinal, multimodal dataset in children, which includes behavioral measures, cognitive assessments, structural and functional MRI measures, magnetoencephalography, and (epi)genomics data. The project provided training in experimental design, multisite study coordination and harmonization, data analysis, result presentation and publication to over 50 graduate students, 20 postdoctoral students, and 20 junior faculty resulting in 255 publications. This ambitious project has revealed differences in brain development due to sex and pubertal status as well as interactions with age. Consistent with prior literature, children recruited to the study were exposed to a range of traumatic experiences, ranging from natural disasters to living in a hostile neighborhood. The experiences of this study cohort have led to new insights into how trauma exposure influences both brain structure and function in otherwise typically developing children. We also have evidence consistent with prior preclinical studies that genetics influence the brain’s response to trauma. The sites developed a number of new analysis techniques to facilitate multimodal integration, which allowed for the generalization of results both across tasks and across imaging techniques. The novel analysis techniques provide further insight into how brain structure and function change across adolescence. The project team also provided science outreach activities to children through participation in local science events, presentations in schools, and locally-provided neuroscience education events reaching over 5000 students across all three jurisdictions. Every summer, high school and undergraduate students were invited to participate in a research internship program to perform research within a DevCoG faculty member’s lab. The students presented the result of their work either as an oral or poster presentation at the end of the internship. Individuals traditionally under-represented in the sciences were prioritized. This opportunity, designed specifically for individuals from the three jurisdictions, provided hands-on science experience to over 50 students who represented the ethnic and racial diversity of the local jurisdictions. The leadership team continues to collaborate through multiple grant submissions and the currently funded DevMIND study. Each jurisdiction continues to benefit from this productive collaboration through use of the multimodal dataset for grant applications and publications.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Julia Stephen
